Ask HN: How was your move back to India?
text:
I’ve been living abroad for about five or six years now and I’m wondering whether returning back to India and living in Bangalore makes sense.

One of the biggest motivator of the move is that in India I don’t need a visa to do anything and that makes running a startup easier. Also from the outside looking in it seems like something special is brewing back in Bangalore. If I want to sell B2B SaaS it seems like a nice place where I’ll have possible customers all around me. The weather in Bangalore is quite nice too. The worries about a possible move back to India are inefficiencies in daily life - the traffic, long queues at airports, pollution, not enough green spaces, comparably worse infrastructure. All this said it seems like a good place to chase outsized out comes - alumni from college are in startups around the city and in VC, unicorns seem fairly frequent. I’d not move back with the intent of working for someone else.

The other options for me would be to live in cities like London, Toronto or East/West coast. The first two I could get residence or a startup visa even. The US seems like a different beast all together where residence/visa seems incredibly tough to navigate. For startup operators who have worked both in London/Toronto and Bangalore, how do they compare? The best thing I love about living abroad is that the basics mostly simply work & people around you generally don’t care about what you’re doing allowing you to operate. Through years of living abroad I’ve some networks in these cities (mostly alums from bigtech jobs).

Ask HN: The least energy-consuming device able to run Lisp
text: The question is not about an energy-efficient device where every operation takes a minimum amount of energy, but about the device which may run REPL with any Lisp dialect as long as possible using a constant amount of energy. Performance may be absurdly slow. Input-output devices may be considered out of equation.

Ask HN: What makes Wear OS watches and Apple watches run out of battery quickly?
text: I own a Mi Watch, and by deactivating some features, it can last me about a month on a single charge, I am wondering why Apple and Google can't achieve such autonomy with their operating systems, what makes their software consume more battery than Xiaomi's software ?

Show HN: Find, Join or Create RnD projects; get your creative juices flowing
text:
Hello fellow startup-ers,

I am delighted to introduce baoRnD to you. baoRnD stands for Open and Borderless Research and Development. Aside from RnD tools, what you can do on baoRnD includes:

create RnD projects for people to follow or support get support (including financial, material, etc) find RnD projects to work on. find other researchers to work on your RnD project. find equipment/lab space for your RnD work others Think of baoRnD as GitLab + LinkedIn but for projects involving little or no code. it does not mean programmers cannot use baoRnD (in fact some are using it) but there are currently products better suited for programmers than baoRnD.

Get your creative juices flowing today.

Please support us by signing up or joining the waitlist.

You can contact me with feedback on aa@baornd.com
